ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: RF power dependence of refractive index of room temperature sputtered ZnO:Al thin films

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Material Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The deposition power dependence of visible transmittance and refractive index of room temperature-deposited ZnO:Al thin films by RF magnetron sputtering has been studied. All films exhibited high visible transmittance and near-complete UV absorption. The refractive index of the films decreased continuously with an increase in the RF power at all photon energies in the visible and near-IR region, which has been partially attributed to the decreased packing density of the films. For each film, the refractive index exhibited strong frequency dispersion in the weak-absorption region. The origin of optical dispersion at different RF power has been discussed in the light of a single-oscillator model.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In recent years, ZnO:Al thin films have drawn much attention because of their huge potential in a wide range of applications including flat-panel displays, solar cells, organic light emitting diodes, etc. [1–3]. Among the variety of techniques employed to grow these thin films, RF magnetron sputtering from a compound target, which often provides films of resistivity as low as order of 10−4 Ω cm and high visible transparency, has been widely used. In literature, extensive work on films grown by RF magnetron sputtering has been reported, which has revealed a significant dependence of film properties on the process parameters [4–7]. Deposition power and substrate temperature in the sputtering technique have been identified to be critical in that they affect structure and compositional non-stoichiometry [4–13].

Typically, a high substrate temperature in the range of 200–300 °C has been required to yield thin films of desirable structural ordering [5, 6]. This temperature range, however, is incompatible with flexible transparent plastic substrates or sensitive photoresists used in light emitting diodes and solar cells. Thus, there have been growing efforts to realize processing of ZnO:Al thin films without intentional substrate heating. On the other hand, in contrast to the high temperature deposition, during the low temperature deposition the adatoms have relatively lower mobility on the growing surface, which may result in poor structural ordering of the films [7]. In such cases, the effects of the deposition power are expected to be significant, since the deposition power can directly affect the energy and rate of arrival of the bombarding particles, and hence the eventual transport and optical properties of the films [8–13].

Concerning typical optical properties of ZnO:Al thin films grown by RF magnetron sputtering, there are many reports available in literature. However, studies pertaining to a systematic correlation of deposition power with optical parameters, especially transmittance and refractive index, are very limited in room temperature grown conducting films. The few studies, which deal with effects of deposition power in the room temperature-deposited films, primarily concern with only visible transmittance/reflectance and optical band gap of the films [14–16]. For example, Selmi et al. have reported the variation in optical transmittance and reflectance of ZnO:Al thin films grown by RF magnetron sputtering of a compound target [14]. Rahmane et al. have studied the effects of RF power on optical band gap and Urbach energy of the ZnO:Al films deposited by reactive sputtering [16]. Surprisingly, a detailed study on deposition power dependence of the refractive index (and its dispersion) of the ZnO:Al thin films grown at the room temperature is not available in literature. In this work, the films grown by RF magnetron sputtering from a compound target under varying RF power (50–200 W) onto glass substrates are investigated by focusing on the RF power dependence of near-IR absorption and refractive index.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: ZnO:Al thin films were deposited on glass substrates at room temperature (∼30 °C) by RF magnetron sputtering as described earlier [17]. The substrates were held parallel to the target at a distance of about 6 cm. A water-cooled 2-inch compound target containing ZnO and 2.0 wt% Al2O3 was used for the sputtering (Williams Advanced Materials, Buffalo, NY). The sputtering was carried out at various RF powers in the range of 50 to 200 W at 13.56 MHz in pure Ar ambient. The chamber was turbo-pumped to a base pressure lower than 2×10−6 Torr. The flow of Ar into the chamber was controlled by a mass flow controller and was fixed at 65 SCCM in order to maintain a working pressure of 2 mTorr. Since the ZnO:Al thin films are reported to exhibit considerable variations of properties with respect to position in the sample [18], the central portion of the samples of size of about 15 mm×15 mm was used for subsequent characterizations.

Under the given experimental conditions, the rate of deposition increased linearly with RF power at a rate of ∼0.24 nm min−1 W−1 and there exists a threshold power of ∼17 W for effective deposition [17]. The approximate thickness of the films is given in Table 1. Structural properties were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a PANalytical model X’Pert PRO XRD unit using Cu-K α radiation in Bragg–Brentano (θ/2θ) geometry. Dark resistivity, Hall mobility, and carrier concentration were measured at room temperature using a standard Hall measurement system (Ecopia 21, Model: HMS-3000) in van der Pauw configuration. Optical transmittance and reflectance of the films in the wavelength region of 250 to 2000 nm were measured by a spectrophotometer (JASCO V530).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Typical optical transmittance and reflectance spectra of the ZnO:Al thin films grown at various RF power at room temperature are shown in Fig. 1. The oscillatory character of the curves is due to the interference effect arising due to multiple reflections at the interfaces [19]. All films exhibited visible transmittance better than 75 % (note that the effects due to the substrate were not corrected, and the values go significantly higher after the corrections) and near-complete absorption in the UV region. With increase in the RF power, the fundamental absorption edge became gentler with marginal decrease in both transmittance and reflectance in the visible region. At near-IR, however, the effect of the RF power was well manifested: The transmittance of the films decreased sharply, the onset of the fall in transmittance being blue-shifted with increase in the RF power. The decrease in transmission in the near-IR is due to the free carrier absorption. Qualitatively, the fall in transmittance is described by the plasma frequency ω
p given by [19]
1
$$ \omega_{{p}} \sim \bigl(n{e}^{2} /\varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{\infty}{m}^{*}\bigr)^{1/2} $$ where n is the carrier concentration, m ∗ is the electron effective mass, ε 0 is the permittivity of free space, and ε ∞ is the residual dielectric constant. As given in Table 1, our previous results of the Hall measurement showed that the carrier concentration n increased significantly about 1.1×1018 to 8.9×1020 cm−3 for the increase in the RF power from 50 to 200 W [17]. Thus, as expected from Eq. (1), with increase in n, the plasma frequency is shifted to higher frequencies, as depicted in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1
Energy dependence of optical transmittance and reflectance spectra of ZnO:Al thin films grown with various RF power. The dashed lines at top and bottom correspond respectively to transmittance and reflectance of the glass substrates

The above presented transmittance data were used to estimate the refractive index of the films and the variation of the same with RF power was investigated. The refractive index n
f of the films in the wavelength region with only weak optical absorption can be given by the relation [20],
2
$$ \begin{aligned} & n_{f}^{2} = N + \bigl(N^{2} - n_{s}^{2}\bigr)^{_{1/2}} \\ & N =\frac{2n_{s}(T_{\max} - T_{\min} )}{T_{\max} \times T_{\min}} + \frac{n_{s}^{2} + 1}{2} \end{aligned} $$ where n
s is the refractive index of the substrate (assumed to be 1.53 for the glass slides), and T max and T min are values on the comprehensive lines drawn through maximum transmittance and minimum transmittance, respectively, which arises due to the interference effects. In literature, Eq. (2) has been successfully used to evaluate refractive index of a variety of thin films [20–25]. Figure 2 shows the variation in refractive index of the ZnO:Al thin films as a function of RF power at three different photon energies. The refractive index of the films decreased continuously with increase in the RF power at all photon energies. The n
f values obtained for all samples in this region of wavelength were between 1.80 to 2.00, which is similar to the reported values for ZnO and ITO thin films [26, 27].
Fig. 2
Plot of variation in refractive index n
f of ZnO:Al thin films as a function of RF power. The solid lines are guides to the eye

The refractive index of the films in the weak absorbance region was modeled with a dispersion formula corresponding to a single oscillator function [28],
3
$$ n_{f}^{2} = 1 + \frac{E_{d}E_{0}}{E_{0}^{2} - (h\nu )^{2}} $$ where E 0=hν 0 is the single effective oscillator energy and E
d is the dispersion energy that measures the strength of interband optical transition. A linear variation of
$1/(n_{{f}}^{2}-1)$ with (hν)2 obtained for the ZnO:Al thin films grown at various RF powers is shown in Fig. 3. It indicates that a single oscillator model gives a good description to the optical dispersion in the weak-absorbance (transparent) region. The oscillator energy E 0 and dispersion energy E
d were estimated from the slope and zero energy intercept from the plot of
$1/(n_{{f}}^{2}-1)$ versus (hν)2. The results are shown in Fig. 4. This figure also shows the variation in two other important parameters, namely, the average oscillator strength S 0=E
d
E 0/h 2 c 2 and the long wavelength dielectric constant ε ∞=1+E
d /E 0. The values for E 0, E
d , and S 0 increased with increase in RF power up to 150 W and decreased marginally for further increase of the RF power. The long wavelength dielectric constant ε ∞ continuously decreased from 3.69 at 50 W to 3.28 at 200 W. The values, nevertheless, are in a range similar to the ones previously reported for the sputtered ZnO thin films [24]. The smaller values of the long wavelength refractive index with increasing RF power suggest the probability of lower energy transition [29]. From the range of the oscillator energy (Fig. 4), it is found that the maximum optical transition occurred near the energy range 8.5–16.5 eV. These values are significantly higher than the band gap of the corresponding samples, indicating that the optical dispersion in the weak absorbance region is mainly due to the higher critical point virtual transitions and not by the fundamental band gap energy [29].
Fig. 3
Plot of
$1/(n_{{f}}^{2}-1)$ vs. (hν)2 of ZnO:Al thin films grown at various RF power. Symbols denote the experimental data and solid lines are the linear fits
Fig. 4
Variations in fitting parameters, E
d , E 0, S 0, and ε ∞, of a single-oscillator model for the dispersion curves of refractive index of the samples grown at different RF power

Concerning the effect of RF power, it is worth noting that for all energies, n
f decreased continuously with increase in the RF power (Fig. 2). It has been shown that the refractive index of thin films can be affected significantly by packing density and lattice contraction: the lattice contraction resulted in decrease of refractive index whereas increase in packing density due to reduction voids led to increase of refractive index [24, 28, 30]. Following the earlier reports, the packing density P of the films grown at different RF powers was calculated from the experimental values of the refractive indices and lattice parameters using the relation [24, 25, 30, 31]
4
$$\begin{aligned} n_{f} =& \sqrt{\frac{(1 - P)n_{v}^{4} + (1 + P)n_{v}^{2}n_{b}^{2}}{(1 + P)n_{v}^{2} + (1 - P)n_{b}^{2}}} \\ &{}+ \frac{5}{2}\biggl( \frac{n_{b}^{2} -1}{n_{b}} \biggr) \biggl( \frac{c_{f} - c_{b}}{c_{b}} \biggr) \end{aligned}$$ where n
v is the refractive index of the voids (= 1 for air), n
b is the refractive index of the single crystal (assumed to be equal to 2.0 at 2.75 eV), c
f is the unit cell parameter of the films and c
b is the unit cell parameter for the reference sample (= 5.2066 Å) (JCPDS file: 36-1451). The detailed structure and morphology of the films as a function of increasing RF power have been discussed in our earlier report [17]. The deposition at 50 W resulted in the formation of a highly c-axis oriented film, as revealed from the XRD pattern of the film that contained only two peaks corresponding to the (002) and (004) planes of the hexagonal-wurtzite structure. As the deposition power was increased, several additional minor peaks appeared in the XRD patterns indicating increased polycrystallinity of the films. For use in Eq. (4), the lattice parameter c
f was calculated from the position of the (002) peak in the XRD pattern of the films. The values of c
f of the films grown at different RF power are given in Table 1. While the first term in Eq. (4) shows the contribution from the packing density, the second term represents that from the lattice contraction. Since for all samples studied here c
f is larger than c
b , both the terms in Eq. (4) are additive. The results on the calculation of packing density are shown in Fig. 5 as expressed with the variation (%) in packing density (ΔP) from the 50 W value. The films grown at 50 W was found to have packing density of ∼96 % while that of the 200 W film had only 89 %, which is nearly 7 % less than that of the 50 W film. With increase in RF power, the packing density tended to decrease, particularly showing the sudden decrease after 100 W. The trend is very similar to the variations of refractive index with RF power in Fig. 2. Accordingly, the packing density is regarded as a critical parameter for explaining the dependence of the refractive index on RF power in the room temperature sputtered ZnO thin films.
Fig. 5
Change in packing density (%) of the films at different RF power with respect to the films grown at 50 W

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Specific optical parameters, namely transmittance and refractive index of the ZnO:Al thin films prepared at room temperature by RF magnetron sputtering have been investigated. While all films exhibited high transmittance in the visible region, at near-IR, the transmittance decreased sharply, the onset of the fall in transmittance being red-shifted with the increase in the RF power due to the increased free carrier absorption. For each film, the refractive index exhibited strong frequency dispersion below the interband absorption edge and is in good agreement with a single-oscillator model. The result on the calculation of packing density suggests that packing density is one of the critical parameters in understanding the dependence of refractive index with RF power.
